channel.title: Alternative to IP Banning
channel.description:
I was thinking of a way to permanently ban players without banning their IP necessarily. What if you had your client write a new file somewhere on your computer that had a certain code assigned to each account and you would get banned by having that certain code on the banned list.
Discuss.

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @the_elve_age the elve age
item.description:
@the_elve_age wrote:

Have your client with 5+ verification methods haha. Good suggestions.

Read full topic

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Just some ideas:

MAC Address
Process: Client determines current network interface address, and sends it to the server
Pro: Requires more effort for the user to get around
Con: Tools exist to easily change the MAC Address, and change it randomly based on time

Subnet
Process: Server adds last octet (subnet) of the connecting IP to the blacklist
Pro: Changing your IP at the router level doesn’t affect the subnet
Con: There are a limited number of IPv4 addresses, and people in the same neighborhood may have the same subnet address provided by the ISP

Client UID
Process: Randomly generated, or preset number set by the server operator, is sent to the server when a login attempt is made.
Pro: Allows the server operator more control over who can connect.
Con: Very easy to change, not much security.

Client UID - Checksum
Process: Generate numbers that are put into an algorithm, and always return a specified result (look at ISBN numbers)
Pro: In addition to the previous pro, any random tinkering will produce an invalid result.
Con: If the user knows the method you’re using, they have more knowledge, and can fine-tune the tweaking to produce valid results.

Online Registration
Process: Have an online form for user creation, required a captcha/other form of “human-checking”, sending an email to the user, finish verifaction there.
Pro: More effort is required, making people less willing to bypass the ban.
Con: Requires more effort from the user to get to play the game.

Read full topic

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:23, topic:460023”][quote author=the elve age link=topic=562933.msg4105604#msg4105604 date=1347928751]
^ I’m not worried about an average kid getting around the id; I’m worried about that annoying ass who finds it.
[/quote]

You could rename the files + methods. Most people won’t bother if they can’t find the main method names nor the class name at all. MAC address bans are easy to get around – if someone is annoying enough and they know what they’re doing, they could easily realize it’s more than an IP ban and decompile the client. Then they can change their MAC address easily (if using linux it’s only a few commands):

There are a lot of reasons you might want to manually set your MAC address for your network card. I won’t ask you what your reason is.

To change this setting, we’ll need to edit the /etc/network/interfaces file. You can choose to use a different editor if you’d like.

You should see the line for your network interface, which is usually eth0. If you have dhcp enabled, it will look like this:

auto eth0 iface eth0 inet dhcp

Just add another line below it to make it look something like this:

auto eth0 iface eth0 inet dhcp hwaddress ether 01:02:03:04:05:06

Obviously you would want to choose something else for the MAC address, but it needs to be in the same format.

You will need to restart networking or reboot to take effect.

A good way to slow down people from making useless accounts (and to evade bans) is requiring the user to validate their email and click the link sent to their email. Eventually that person won’t be fucked to make another email.[/quote]
bcel works too.

Read full topic

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

the elve age:

^ I’m not worried about an average kid getting around the id; I’m worried about that annoying ass who finds it.

You could rename the files + methods. Most people won’t bother if they can’t find the main method names nor the class name at all. MAC address bans are easy to get around – if someone is annoying enough and they know what they’re doing, they could easily realize it’s more than an IP ban and decompile the client. Then they can change their MAC address easily (if using linux it’s only a few commands):

There are a lot of reasons you might want to manually set your MAC address for your network card. I won’t ask you what your reason is.

To change this setting, we’ll need to edit the /etc/network/interfaces file. You can choose to use a different editor if you’d like.

You should see the line for your network interface, which is usually eth0. If you have dhcp enabled, it will look like this:

auto eth0 iface eth0 inet dhcp

Just add another line below it to make it look something like this:

auto eth0 iface eth0 inet dhcp hwaddress ether 01:02:03:04:05:06

Obviously you would want to choose something else for the MAC address, but it needs to be in the same format.

You will need to restart networking or reboot to take effect.

A good way to slow down people from making useless accounts (and to evade bans) is requiring the user to validate their email and click the link sent to their email. Eventually that person won’t be fucked to make another email.

Read full topic

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:20, topic:460023”][quote author=the elve age link=topic=562933.msg4105326#msg4105326 date=1347914943]

Simple to get around, therefore pointless to implement.
[/quote]How? You could make the file only client-accessible (possibly give it priorities such as Win7 files?). Also, the player wouldn’t know that they had the file on their computer (unless they were told or found it).

@T4, Ip-range banning would still be easily avoided.

That won’t work, and anybody could easily find any ‘secret files’ (using a sandbox for example).[/quote]
Considering the average person you have to an is a kid that thinks setting environmental variables is pro, I doubt any of them know what a sandbox is anyway.

Read full topic

[/quote]How? You could make the file only client-accessible (possibly give it priorities such as Win7 files?). Also, the player wouldn’t know that they had the file on their computer (unless they were told or found it).

@T4, Ip-range banning would still be easily avoided.[/quote]
That won’t work, and anybody could easily find any ‘secret files’ (using a sandbox for example).

item.description:

Ruby:

I would honestly strongly advise mac address bans. I know it’s easy to change your mac address, but if people don’t know the banning method then how would they solve it.

True, mac address banning isn’t exactly a common feature. No one would guess, and if they did then it would be a pretty uncommon occurrence I would expect.

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

having an ip filter of known proxies (bopm is an example of an irc bot that does this) would be a good idea. mac address banning isn’t fool proof, but also a good idea. ip-range banning might also be worth looking into.

[quote=“RandQm, post:10, topic:460023”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=562933.msg4103913#msg4103913 date=1347785340]
I like the idea, you could also add in a mac address ban.
[/quote]
You can’t reach a mac address outside a private network.
DNS banning might work[/quote]
the client send the address you fool. dns banning…? what the fuck is that?

Read full topic

item.title: Alternative to IP Banning
item.dc:creator: @Nebulae Nebulae
item.description:
@Nebulae wrote:

Maybe some type of encrypted file that the players must have in a certain location/activated to access the client, so just before the update server you could have a verification server.

Obviously then if they decide to remove it they won’t even be able to access the client to start with, and it’s encrypted with whatever is the best type of encryption method, and even if they did manage to decrypt the file, it has to be that actual file that was created by downloading the client for the first time (maybe contains a unique signature to verify that the file is the actual file and not a duplicated version).

That’s my theory on what you could do. A bit like how you have to have the No-IP DUC running to access a server.

Read full topic
